  "project_scope": "Notes highlight: CBRE Labour: 4 Regular hours:  Ensure Fire panel is bypassed / provide access to VESDA Panels for Batteries replacement0.5 Regular Hours:  Ensure full completion of install / restore fire panel / Vendor sign-off. Problem identified: CBRE Operations with Vendor (VIPOND) to replace controlled power Batteries located in F4, G4 and Electrical rooms inside the VESDA control cabinets.. Replacement to take place due to its age and years of service.  360 solutions. to properly recycle all used batteries extracted and provide disposal certification. Scope includes: CBRE with VIPOND to bypass both F4 and G4 Vesda system for the duration of batteries replacement.  Once completed Fire system will be restored and back to full monitoring, free of alarms. Justification: VRLA batteries in these particular modules are recommended for replacement at a range of 3 - 5 years of service, This battery system with age loses its ability to maintain greater than 80% capacity, Replacement is recommended. The reason for the strict set of rules governing the disposal of batteries is that lead-acid batteries are largely composed of 60-75% [by weight] lead [Pb], lead-dioxide [PbO2] and a sulfuric acid solution electrolyte. This heavy metal element makes them toxic and improper disposal can be hazardous to the environment. Improper and illegal disposal of lead-acid batteries show up in the form of pollution of our drinking water, and food produced from ingredients exposed to small and moderate levels of lead content. Effect if not approved: As these batteries age, a decline on its rating is also impacted. This decline could be a result of internal corrosion and expansion of the plate grids, possible drying of the electrolytes. recommendations.

· Each power loss supervisory device shall be tested by disconnecting the main power supply to the equipment, resulting in a audible trouble 
signal and visual indication.
· Other fixed type extinguishing systems that are connected to the fire alarm control unit, the owner to co ordinate the operation of the output 
contacts so that Simplex can verify it initiates the specified system functions at the fire alarm control unit (e.g., alarm, trouble)
· Emergency telephones will be tested and inspected for appropriate operation(s).
